>She the size of a man and a half, and has just as much muscle as even the strongest warriors I've ever seen. Blood soaks her hands, up to the elbow on one of her arms even.
>Once I've recovered from the shock of her sheer size, I was assaulted by her unholy form.
>She looks at me, her body bare save for the occasional jeweled trinket adorning her limbs.
>Praying to my lord to protect me from her unholy temptations, no doubt caused by some wicked spell, I ready myself for what comes next.
>"You...you're no witch. Or at least, you're fairly armored for one. Where is the witch named Gwyndil?"
>Her words somehow hover in the air, hazy sounding and slow creeping into my ears. It takes an uncomfortable amount of time to parse her odd voice before I understand what she has said.
>I'm racking my brain for a Gwyndil, and all that comes to mind is my soft speaking grandmother, who had long past when I was a child. Surely, she was no witch. The paladins would have detected her back when father was knighted himself, as they were mere feet from our family during the ceremony.
>"Speak, human. I seek the witch Gwyndil. Does she still live?" Once again, her clouded words fill the air, hanging as my ears as I struggle to brush away the haze of her voice.
>Finding my own voice, I become keenly aware of how dry my throat as become. "Gwyndil Rackor died many years ago," I finally speak up. Realizing that if I stop here, I may falter, so I take a step forward, pointing the tip of my blade at the demon, "And she was no witch, demon! In the name of the Lord and for sullying my family name, fall by my blade!"
>I rush the blood covered she-demon, only for her to almost casually slap at my sword. Rather than simply redirect the attack, she shatters my weapon, rendering it useless in my hand. Before I can adjust, her soaked palm comes forward, and as the air in my lungs leave me, my back finds the stone wall behind me.

>My question goes ignored as she leans back, once again thinking to herself as she stares into the stone wall above me, as if looking past it.

>"The witch's first born. How did they die, knight?" Her attention snaps back to me, red eyes intense as she stares. It was if the answer to her question was written on my skin with how focused she was on me.

That also means I'm the last of our battalion still inside the keep.

>It's hard to keep track of time. Between how her voice distorts itself in my ears, and the lack of any candles or ways to see the open skies, I'm having trouble telling how long she has been silent.
>"So," the demon finally speaks up, "The witch passed peacefully, and so does her child." I grit my teeth as she once again accuses my grandmother of witchcraft, but swallow my pointless anger instead. I am at her complete mercy. To struggle and fight would only ensure a pointless death.

With Hell's might, they will fall." There is no cloudiness in her words as they ring into my head. >I'm on the floor of the kitchen, clawing and crawling like a child as I try to find my coordination. The warmth is still in my chest; nowhere near as bad as what felt like mere moments ago, but too hot to ever ignore. "You awaken." The demon. Still very much real as she looms in the broken door.

Anonymous Wed 07 Jun 2017 15:29:13 No.9758392 Report
Quoted By:
>>9756860
My experience so far with the game does not make me feel like it is SJW. There might be parts that an SJW would like, like the fact the main character is bi, and she has two gay friends, but it does not really feel preachy in the sense you would expect an SJW game to be. The gay characters aren't really treated as anything special, just a couple that happens to be two guys. No one makes a big deal about it. The characters are treated as being flawed. It's clear that mae doesn't really have her shit together and can be insensitive. Gregg (the gay guy) is reckless, and Mae actually follows along with his terrible ideas, which ends up with her being fried by electricity. The straight (as far as I can tell) Bea actually calls Mae out on some of the shit that she does.

I can see some parts that an SJW would like, but the game itself is good in my opinion. The fanbase can be crap at times, but most fanbases are. Perhaps check out a short walkthrough, and see what you think.

Anonymous Fri 09 Jun 2017 05:00:41 No.9788581 Report
Quoted By: >>9789568
>>9787674
I won't even act like I have the right to dictate what other people do. It's just that in any situation where you say 'All <x>s are <y> manner,' one of the first responses is "But why?" Or, in this case, someone stating that, with no explanation, <x>'s being <y> make no sense (See: >>9785518 , >>9785613).

Let me just flat out state that I don't give two shits about using domesticated species or not. For me, anthros have just been there all along and no one is wondering who the fuck bred anthro corgis into existence.

What is likely his problem is that the line was drawn between domesticated species and 'wild' species, and he was wondering "Well, who made drew this line? Who brought all these domesticated breeds of dog into existence when anthros are actually people and not real life dogs? Who decides who is domesticated and who is not? This is dumb, and wouldn't work." It's most likely because it's a line that relies on out of world/reader knowledge, because bringing up who is a domesticated species or not in the written setting would just be bizarre. Imagine a sparrow calling a chicken domesticated as an insult, and it opens up the tangled matter of "Wait, why and how do they know who is domesticated or not?" It creates this bizarre scenario where nobody is actually, really domesticated but people are still aware somehow, in setting, aware that some species are 'wild' and others are not.

To which any setting creator could just say "It's like that because I said so and don't actually care about the why" and the reader would most likely call that retarded, but that's just how it would be. Again, it's just rules of story telling. If you have a major detail in a setting, you have to explain why the detail is so vital or how it came to be, because 'it just is that way' tends to upset people.

Granted, just going 'because my fetish demands it' in smut writing tends to a good enough hand wave, but it still can upset people. Obviously.

I'mma break it down for you real simple

If domestication was literally never a thing in this setting, why would 'domesticated' be a label to put on someone? There would be another term to describe this submissive tendency, surely. Imagine two dude bros having a conversation about what kind of women to get. "Oh man, you gotta lose your girl and get an anthro. One of the domesticated kind, like a sheep or somethin.'"

This doesn't make sense, because domestication is not a thing that happened. No one would refer to a sheep as domesticated, since in-universe, it wouldn't make sense as a term for anyone to use. Not unless you also have non-anthro animals that are domesticated around to compare them to, which opens up a whole 'nother, particularly ethical, can of worms just to justify things in-universe. You could literally just write it as 'some anthros are just more submissive,' and these anthros just HAPPEN to be domesticated species in reality and be done with it.

If at any time you have to write "And because she was a cow, she obeyed his commands" or anything equally direct, you TOLD the reader instead of simply SHOWING the reader through repeated interactions that the anthros they know as domesticated species tend to be submissive. That's just bad writing.

I've got no problem with your 'some anthros are just submissive' business, that's your bag, whatever. I don't care. It's that the manner that you're going about it is hamfisted as hell. Nobody is attacking you for wanting realism, you fragile pansy.

>Why?
Because domestication wouldn't be a thing. There wouldn't 'house cats.' They would just be cats, albeit ranging from small to huge. No, my solution is to not call to the fact that some anthro animals are wild in the real world and some we raised to have specific traits through generations and centuries of careful breeding.

In this wondrous hypothetical setting, 'domestic' refers to species of anthros who easily integrated with other species back in the early centuries and formed societies and cities. 'Wild' refers to species that resisted 'standard' civilization akin to the steppe nomads of Asia and the xenophobic tribes of South America and Africa.

Done. You now have a backed up, defined reason to use the specific term 'domesticated' if you're so anal about it. Now it's not awkward writing that relies on out of universe knowledge instead of being explained in text, with the bonus of actually making the setting interesting and giving it history.

We're done here, I fixed the hole in this idea myself and came out better for it. Might actually even use it, too.
